entry.title: Re: Regarding the transpo of filter variants per app.rt
entry.content: Hi and thanks for your question.The variants (aka "views") you're referring to are usually personal to the user that created them and cannot be moved via transports across systems. However, if certain requirements are met, views can be saved as "public" so they are available for other users. The "public" feature needs to be available and enabled for your platform to do this. If this is an option for you, please check the following documentation as an entry point: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4fc8d03390c342da8a60f8ee387bca1a/cf0191775b1f4ba19748552991a06465.html?locale=en-US There are other key user features in this documentation that might help you to adapt UIs to your scenarios. Best regards, Oliver

entry.title: Re: Regarding the transpo of filter variants per app.rt
entry.content:
Hi and thanks for your question.

The variants (aka "views") you're referring to are usually personal to the user that created them and cannot be moved via transports across systems.

However, if certain requirements are met, views can be saved as "public" so they are available for other users. The "public" feature needs to be available and enabled for your platform to do this. If this is an option for you, please check the following documentation as an entry point (as Henrike suggested): Create Public Views.  There are other key user features in this documentation that might help you to adapt UIs to your scenarios.

Best regards, Oliver

entry.title: Re: Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
After the successful deployment we are missing a very important feature - the automatic certificate update for the SAML certificates. Running the "wizard" in SAP Ariba Intelligent Configuration Manager creates the necessary applications in the SAP CIS but the Metadata URL is always empty. This means that every time the certificates of "service-eu.ariba.com" or "s1-eu.ariba.com" are updated, one needs to manually re-download the metadata.xml from SAP Ariba and re-upload it into the SAP CIS. Apparently, the SAP CIS would attempt to update the SAML certificates if the target application das a Metadata URL available.

Other solution, like SAP SuccessFactors provide an Metadata URL that can be added to SAP CIS. Is this at least planned for SAP Ariba too? It would be very useful (actually necessary) since DigiCert intends to issue certificates with reduced lifecycle - 47 days by Mar-2029. Thanks!

entry.title: AI innovations highlights in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
The release of SAP Cloud ERP 2602 continues SAP‚Äôs focus on embedding intelligence directly into business processes, quietly, purposefully, and where it matters most. In this blog, you‚Äôll find a guided look at the key AI innovations introduced with the 2602 release, as highlighted in the product blog post by Bert Schulze. Rather than showcasing AI as a standalone capability, the focus is on how these innovations support customers in running, adapting, and evolving their core business processes across finance, sales, manufacturing, procurement, and beyond.

With the 2602 release, SAP Cloud ERP builds on its existing foundation by supporting everyday work with intelligence that is more contextual, connected, and task focused. At the heart of this evolution is an agentic AI framework, where specialized, task-specific agents take on clearly defined responsibilities based on real business context, data, and rules. These agents work together behind the scenes, while Joule serves as the orchestration layer that brings insights, recommendations, and next steps together in a natural, conversational way. Whether supporting a finance expert with complex classifications or helping teams respond faster to operational issues, intelligence is applied exactly where decisions are made. Take a moment to explore the accompanying video for a closer look at how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and point toward a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

Take a look at the short video below to see how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and are shaping a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

 

Agentic AI use case highlights

Finance

International Trade Classification Agent (beta)

When a single misclassified product can delay a shipment or trigger compliance questions, international trade classification quickly becomes a task where precision matters as much as speed. Inthe 2602 release, the International Trade Classification Agent supports product classification specialists in this sensitive part of the process by reasoning over product characteristics and applicable trade regulations. It proposes customs tariff numbers and commodity codes and explains how each recommendation was derived, making review and approval straightforward. This shifts the expert‚Äôs role from manual lookup to informed validation, while keeping full transparency and auditability. In practice, teams can expect significantly less effort spent on repetitive classification tasks, up to a 50% reduction, while lowering the risk of non-compliance.

 

Accounting Accruals Agent

Period-end accruals are a familiar pressure point in finance: important, repetitive, and often constrained by tight timelines. The beta version of the Accounting Accruals Agent tackles this challenge by supporting teams with proposing accruals based on accounting policy documents, historical data, and calculated values, helping shift the work from manual preparation to focused review. Accrual proposals are presented directly in the ‚ÄòManage Accrual Proposals‚Äô app, along with clear explanations that show how each figure was derived. This transparency makes it easier for general ledger accountants to validate and post accruals with confidence, without losing control over the process. As a result, teams can reduce the time spent on period-end activities while maintaining consistency and auditability, supporting a smoother close cycle.

For more information, see Accounting Accruals Agent.

 

Embedded AI highlights

Sales

Automatic creation of sales orders from unstructured data (premium) - AnyDOX adoption

Sales teams often receive purchase orders in formats that don‚Äôt fit neatly into systems, PDFs attached to emails, scanned documents, or images that still require careful manual entry. With the current release, internal sales representatives can upload these unstructured files and let the system extract the relevant information into a sales order request, proposing values such as the sold-to party based on the document content. What used to be a repetitive transcription task becomes a short review step, allowing sales teams to focus more on customer interactions and less on administrative work. Multilanguage support and the ability to train the extraction logic through SAP Document AI help ensure the process works reliably across regions and document types. The result is a smoother order intake process that reduces manual effort while keeping sales operations responsive and consistent.

Check out this dedicated page on SAP Help Portal to learn more.

 

Finance

Period comparisons and AI insights for product profitability review booklet

Looking at product profitability often starts with a simple question: What changed and why? The latest enhancements to the product profitability review booklet help sales accountants explore this question more systematically by introducing period comparisons for margins and cost of goods sold. Built-in views for margin overview and COGS breakdown are complemented by AI-generated insights that highlight notable developments between periods, offering guidance on where a closer look may be worthwhile. Additional dimensions, functional currency display, and an extensible CDS view support more flexible market segment analysis without losing consistency. Together with the new commenting feature, this creates a clearer, more connected view of product performance that supports informed discussions and decisions.

For more information, discover enhancements in the product profitability review booklet.

 

Manufacturing

AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing

Creating a new production routing often starts by searching for something that already exists and adapting it to fit, an approach that works, but takes time and careful attention. The newly introduced innovation, AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing, supports production engineers, planners, and master data specialists by identifying similar routings based on material names, descriptions, and bills of material. Instead of rebuilding routings from the ground up, users receive suggestions they can copy and adjust, turning setup work into a focused refinement step. This helps reduce repetitive data entry and lowers the risk of inconsistencies across routings. Over time, teams benefit from faster setup, more consistent master data, and a smoother path from planning to production.

Eager to learn more? Check out our dedicated pages on intelligent scenario to find similar materials for routing proposal and creating a routing using the AI-assisted material search.

 

 

Cross topic: Situation handling

AI-assisted situation handling (beta)

When critical issues surface in day-to-day operations, the real challenge is often not awareness but knowing what to do next. This is where AI-assisted situation handling comes into play, supporting business users by complementing automated alerts with context-aware guidance tailored to their roles and responsibilities. By capturing situation data together with its business context, the system can generate targeted recommendations that help users assess options and act more quickly. Customizable prompts and the ability to incorporate data from SAP, third-party, and external sources ensure that advice reflects real operational conditions. In practice, this leads to faster resolution of situations, cutting response times by up to 70%, and helps teams stay focused on decisions rather than diagnostics.

 

 

Joule innovations highlights

Procurement

Conversational search for local and central purchase requisition status

Tracking the status of a purchase requisition often means switching between apps, systems, and document numbers just to answer a simple question. With the latest updates, conversational search in Joule allows procurement users to ask directly about the status of local or central purchase requisitions and their follow-on documents, without navigating into multiple SAP Fiori apps. Users can reference familiar identifiers, such as requisition numbers, connected-system document IDs, or SAP Ariba cart numbers and receive the relevant status in one place. This shortens the path from question to answer and reduces interruptions in daily work. Over time, procurement teams gain faster visibility into requisition progress and can respond to inquiries with greater confidence and less effort.

 

Conversational search for centrally managed purchase requisition status

Similarly to the innovation described above, conversational search in Joule allows users to check the approval and follow-on document status of centrally managed purchase requisitions without switching between SAP Fiori apps. A simple query is enough to see whether a requisition has progressed to a purchase order, acknowledgment, goods receipt, or invoice receipt. This removes friction from everyday follow-ups and helps teams stay informed without interrupting their workflow. As a result, procurement professionals can respond faster to internal requests and keep processes moving smoothly.

 
Conversational search for central procurement business documents

In central procurement , finding the right document often means knowing exactly where to look and having the time to navigate there. With this release conversational search in Joule allows users to search and filter central procurement business documents simply by asking, whether they are looking for contracts nearing expiration, rejected supplier confirmations, or purchase orders tied to a specific supplier or system. Results are presented together with direct navigation links to the relevant SAP Fiori apps, turning search into a natural entry point rather than a separate task. This makes it easier to move from question to action without breaking focus. Over time, procurement teams gain faster access to the information they need and more confidence in managing centrally governed processes.

 

Don‚Äôt miss: The GenAI extensibility assistant

As we roll out the new 2602 features, we also want to highlight a game-changer from the previous cycle that is rapidly becoming a standard for key users. If you haven't yet explored the GenAI-based extensibility assistant, now is the time. This tool allows key users to generate custom fields and logic simply by describing their requirements in natural language. It‚Äôs not just about speed; it ensures your logic is consistent and "clean core" compliant by design. To see this assistant in action and learn how to enable it, check out this deep dive on extensibility assistant for key users.

 

Summary 

üìΩ Register for our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series! 

Between January 12-16, we are hosting a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. On our landing page you can register for the entire series or pick the sessions most relevant to you. 

üîé Find all our assets  

The release 2602 showcases more than 130 innovation highlights across the portfolio. Check out our release document for all the details!

We at Cloud ERP and SCM Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Re: Maintenance operation status is changed back to "In P...
entry.content:
Hi Simon,

You are right, that is not the intended standard behaviour. The execution of YA02 order type should be the same as YA01 here.

When you click "assign to me", the standard behaviour is to keep that operation visible in the Perform Maintenance Job app, and it adds your ID to the "Person Responsible" on the Work Order operation. It should not be reverting back a status/subphase as you mentioned.

Read up on the app here: https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F5104A')/S35

There are a few configuration settings for that app in SSCUI "Define Control Parameters for Perform Maintenance Job" which you can browse, but none of them are related to your issue.

In your project, have you activated any BADI's at the Work Order level? perhaps some of your custom logic/code is triggering the reset upon work order save?

If you have not done any coding extensions, I would recommend raising a support ticket as someone would need to check exactly what is being triggered upon Work Order save here.

Few screenshots below of my public cloud environment:

Operation assigned to me, stays in list:

Phase Execution, Subphase Ready for Execution:

Cheers, Tim

entry.title: Re: Customized Chart of Account in S/4 HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
You can create own CoA but it can be assigned to company code only as an alternative CoA.

YCOA is default for every company code as operational CoA. You can renumber accounts to your own numbering but you will still need to do the mapping because renumbering requires to give input in pairs : old_number-> new_number

entry.title: SF Recruiting Operators are not able to edit or view filed values in job requisitions
entry.content:
Hello Experts. After the last SF release we faced with the issue when recruiting operators are not able to edit some fields in job requisitions in pre-approved status when the job requisition is sent to them for approval. It worked in the past but stopped at some point. What is weird that it impacted some fields. Picklist fields and Recruiting team with operators. For example, HR Manager receives the job requisition in the HR Manager review route map step but when HR Manager tries to update some if the details such as Job function, Employment type, etc which are picklist fields, he cannot do it. There is no input area available for these fields. Also, recruiting operators assigned to the job requisition are not visible any more. Only field titles. The only field HR can edit is Recruiting Team operator field. I checked the template fields permissions and all looks ok. Does anyone have an idea what can cause it? Did you hear other companies complaining about it? I attached screenshots of what it looks like in the system. Any assistance or advise is highly appreciated. 

BR

Anastasia

entry.title: FPM Custom Page: How to parameterize value help in Macro FilterBar based on current object ID
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I am working with an FPM Custom Page that is accessed via internal navigation, where the page context is a single business object ID.

This page displays the main object along with several 1:n associated entities. For these associations, I am using a Macro FilterBar to allow the user to filter the results based on multiple fields.

The issue is related to value help (value list) behavior in the filter bar:

  • The value helps are generic and not context-aware.

  • They currently show all possible values, regardless of the selected business object ID.

  • As a result, users see value help entries that are not relevant for the current object context.

What I would like to achieve is:

  • Parameterize or filter the value help lists in the Macro FilterBar

  • So that the available values are restricted to those related to the current business object ID

  • Ideally done programmatically or via supported FPM mechanisms

I have checked the FPM Explorer and the API Reference, but I could not find a documented way to influence or filter the value help content of a Macro FilterBar based on the page context.

Is there a recommended or supported approach to:

  • Pass contextual parameters (such as the object ID) to value helps?

  • Or dynamically restrict value help entries in an FPM Custom Page?

Any guidance, hints, or architectural recommendations would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance

entry.title: Re: Document Splitting in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello,

In this post, the answer can help you. 

''Customers cannot deactivate document splitting in S4HC. This is outlined in SAP note 2868475 - SSCUI: Define Document Splitting Characteristics for General Ledger. in the note it does mention the option to create an expert configuration request but still this may not allow to deactivate completely

also once deactivated this would not be able to reactivate later as this would not correct previously posted documents. This is the same on premise where you end up with a conversion.

What you can do is set a constant profit center for non assigned transactions in SSCUI 120100 and in this way although updated the user should not have to enter this

David''

entry.title: Converting to the 3-System Landscape ‚Äì Part 1: What‚Äôs in It for You
entry.content:
Co-Author: Dennis Leslie

For quite some time now, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape has been generally available to our customers. In this landscape, SAP Central Business Configuration is leveraged for implementation, ongoing adaptation and extension of business processes.

This is a significant upgrade from the previous 2-system landscape. For the implementation and ongoing adaptation and extension of business processes, early customers used the so-called Manage Your Solution app. Later adopters were fortunate to use SAP Central Business Configuration from the start.

Now, both 2-system landscape setups can be converted to the advanced 3-system landscape, unlocking numerous benefits, such as:

  • An additional test system for enhanced stability
  • Localization as a self-service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud supporting ~160 countries/regions
  • The parallel line feature for safe testing of data migration and business process extensions
  • Comprehensive extensibility options
  • Additional scope items and configuration settings

Stay tuned for our next blog posts in this blog series and explore the power of the 3-system landscape today! To learn more, check out the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Three-System Landscape page on SAP Community.

Going forward, SAP plans to build more features only available in the 3-system landscape as the capabilities provided by SAP Central Business Configuration and the 3-system landscape are required for these new innovations. To learn more about the advantages and the availability of features that require the 3-system landscape, please see SAP Note 3643616.

If you liked this blog, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

entry.title: Re: Why Does SAP Use the Shortage Date for Storage Cost C...
entry.content:
SAP‚Äôs dynamic lot-sizing (DY) procedure intentionally uses the shortage date as the anchor for storage cost calculation, even if forward scheduling shifts the availability date later. This is not a bug‚Äîit‚Äôs the designed logic: DY always evaluates storage costs starting from the shortage date because the algorithm is based on theoretical inventory coverage, not actual physical availability.

Let me tell you why SAP Uses the shortage Date. Definition in DY logic: According to SAP Help, ‚ÄúStarting from the shortage date, successive requirements are grouped together to form lots until additional storage costs become greater than lot-size independent costs.‚Äù

The purpose is, the shortage date represents the point at which demand is unmet. DY assumes that if procurement were possible, stock would be available from that date onward. Storage costs are calculated relative to this theoretical coverage, not the actual scheduled receipt.

The impact when backward scheduling produces a start date in the past, SAP switches to forward scheduling to determine when the order can realistically be fulfilled. However, this does not alter the DY calculation anchor‚Äîthe shortage date remains the baseline for cost comparison.

For Example
Shortage date: 15 January (first unmet requirement).
Next requirement: 6 April (50 pcs).
Forward scheduled availability: 24 March.
DY calculation: Storage costs are computed as if the 50 pcs were available from 15 January, yielding 81 ‚Äúextra storage days.‚Äù

Formula: Storage Costs = 81‚ãÖ34.02‚ãÖ10‚ãÖ50 / 36500 = 37.74
Interpretation: Even though logistics reality says storage starts on 24 March, DY assumes theoretical coverage from 15 January to compare costs against ordering costs.

You are not miss understanding, this is standard SAP behavior. DY always uses shortage date as the start point for storage cost calculation. It only adjusts availability dates for procurement feasibility, not the cost formula.

If logistics realism is critical: Consider alternative lot-sizing procedures (e.g., fixed lot size, lot-for-lot) or custom enhancements to align storage cost calculation with actual availability.

Hope you get my point.

entry.title: Re: Why Does SAP Use the Shortage Date for Storage Cost Calculation Even After Forward Scheduling?
entry.content: Typing mistake in formula related to Storage Costs = (81 * 34.02 * 10 * 50)/36500 = 37.74$

entry.title: High Impact SAP Data Objects to Clean for an S/4HANA Selective Transition from ECC
entry.content:
*Views Expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Introduction

Moving from SAP ECC to S/4HANA using a Selective Data Transition is not just a technical system conversion,it is a data transformation journey. While selective carve outs allow organizations to migrate only relevant organizational units, time slices, or data sets, poor data quality can jeopardize the entire S/4HANA transformation.S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified data model, stricter checks, and real-time processing mean that legacy inconsistencies tolerated in ECC will cause errors, functional gaps, or performance issues in S/4HANA.

This blog outlines the SAP data objects that require mandatory data cleaning before a selective S/4HANA migration, along with practical examples and rationale for each.

Why Data Cleaning Is Mandatory in a Selective Transition

In a selective approach:

  • Only chosen company codes, plants, or years are migrated

  • Historical inconsistencies become more visible

  • Data is restructured, not simply converted

S/4HANA:

  • Enforces business partner (BP) as a single master

  • Removes many legacy tables

  • Uses real-time reconciliation

  • Requires consistent master and transactional data

Without cleaning, you risk:

  • Migration failures

  • Reconciliation mismatches

  • Broken business processes

  • Delayed go-lives

1. Business Partner (Customer & Vendor)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Duplicate customers/vendors

  • Inconsistent master data across company codes

  • Missing mandatory fields (address, tax, bank details)

  • Vendors acting as customers (and vice versa)

ECC Example

  • Vendor 100045 exists for AP

  • Customer 200078 exists for AR

  • Same legal entity, different tax IDs and addresses

Why This Is Mandatory

In S/4HANA:

  • Customers and Vendors are merged into Business Partner

  • Roles (Customer, Supplier) are assigned to a single BP number

  • Inconsistent data causes CVI (Customer Vendor Integration) errors

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only certain company codes, making duplicates harder to reconcile post-migration. Cleaning ensures:

  • Smooth BP conversion

  • Accurate AR/AP reporting

  • Compliance with S/4 data model

2. Material Master Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Obsolete or unused materials

  • Incomplete views (MM, SD, PP)

  • Invalid units of measure

  • Duplicate material numbers

ECC Example

  • Material created but never used in 8 years

  • Sales view missing for materials with open SD history

  • Base UoM inconsistent with alternative UoM

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time MRP

  • Uses simplified inventory tables (MATDOC)

  • Enforces stricter checks on material consistency

Rationale

Migrating unused or inconsistent materials:

  • Increases migration volume

  • Slows performance

  • Causes MRP and ATP errors

Selective transitions benefit most by reducing material footprint.

3. Chart of Accounts & G/L Accounts

What Needs Cleaning

  • Blocked or unused G/L accounts

  • Accounts without proper account type

  • Inconsistent descriptions across company codes

  • Legacy reconciliation accounts

ECC Example

  • G/L 799999 created for testing, never used

  • Same G/L has different names in different company codes

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Introduces Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

  • FI and CO are merged

  • Reconciliation accounts behave differently

Rationale

Dirty G/L data leads to:

  • Conversion errors

  • Financial reconciliation issues

  • Incorrect financial statements

In selective transitions, only active and relevant accounts should be migrated.

4. Open Financial Transactions (AR/AP)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Cleared documents not properly closed

  • Open items with incorrect statuses

  • Residual items with zero balance

  • Old parked documents

ECC Example

  • Invoice marked as open but cleared manually

  • Zero-balance open items still flagged as open

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time reconciliation

  • No longer tolerates technical inconsistencies

  • Universal Journal requires exact balances

Rationale

Open AR/AP items are always migrated in selective scenarios. Incorrect open items cause:

  • Balance mismatches

  • Failed migrations

  • Post-go-live reconciliation chaos

5. Asset Accounting (FI-AA)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Assets without acquisition values

  • Assets without depreciation areas

  • Retired assets still marked as active

  • Incomplete asset master records

ECC Example

  • Asset created but never capitalized

  • Depreciation area missing for a company code

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses New Asset Accounting only

  • Fully integrated into Universal Journal

  • Legacy asset inconsistencies cannot be converted

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only active assets. Cleaning ensures:

  • Correct depreciation

  • Accurate asset balances

  • Compliance with S/4 FI-AA model

6. Open Logistics Transactions

What Needs Cleaning

  • Open purchase orders with no activity

  • Incomplete deliveries

  • Open production orders never closed

  • Inconsistent goods movements

ECC Example

  • PO created 6 years ago, no GR, no IR

  • Production order technically complete but not closed

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses MATDOC for inventory

  • Enforces strict document flow

  • Real-time stock valuation

Rationale

Open logistics documents are technically migrated, not recreated. Dirty data causes:

  • Stock inconsistencies

  • Migration failures

  • Incorrect inventory valuation

7. Customizing and Organizational Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Unused plants, storage locations

  • Inactive company codes

  • Invalid assignments (plant to company code)

  • Legacy controlling areas

ECC Example

  • Plant exists but no postings in 10 years

  • Company code included but not in scope

Why This Is Mandatory

Selective transitions rely on precise scoping. Invalid org data:

  • Complicates data slicing

  • Causes migration logic conflicts

  • Increases testing effort

Rationale

Clean org structures ensure:

  • Correct selective extraction

  • Lean S/4 system

  • Lower total cost of ownership

8. Custom Code & Z-Objects (Indirect Data Impact)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Z-tables with obsolete data

  • Custom programs using removed tables

  • Hard-coded company codes or years

ECC Example

  • Z-table referencing BKPF/BSEG directly

  • Custom report using VBFA incorrectly

Why This Is Mandatory

While not migrated as data:

  • Custom code processes migrated data

  • Dirty Z-data can break business processes

Rationale

Selective data migration often includes selective Z-data. Cleaning avoids:

  • Runtime errors

  • Incorrect reporting

  • Post-go-live defects

Understand your Business "WHY" for DATA CLEARLY

A Selective S/4HANA transition magnifies data quality issues because only parts of the system are migrated. S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified architecture does not tolerate inconsistencies that ECC allowed for decades.

Mandatory Data Cleaning Ensures:

  • Successful migration runs

  • Accurate financial reconciliation

  • Stable business processes

  • Long-term S/4HANA performance

Key Takeaway:

Data cleansing is not a technical task‚Äîit is a business transformation enabler.

#S4HANA #DATA #DATACLEANSING #MandatoryS4HANADATAOBJECTS #SAPECCtoS4HANA #SelectiveTransformation #DataQuality #ERPTransformation

#LegacyModernization

entry.title: Re: Test limit Tags & labels from Idea TDCP7---test edit posted idea - Status changed to: Needs Info
Re: Clarification on Data Migration Activities ‚Äì Split Va...
entry.content:
Hi, please find below the answers to your questions:

 

  • For the material master, can we use MM17 to change the valuation category? Yes, you can do it in Mass via M17. However this must be done before creating the valuation types of that material.
  • Is it possible to use Migration Cockpit to create valuation type data in the accounting view? If not, what is the recommended approach? Yes, you can create the valuation type using Material Master template in Migration Cockpit. In resume for a material X in plant A; you will have an entry for the plant and another entry for each valuation type.
  • For the stock load with split valuation, can we use Migration Cockpit? If not, what is the best practice? Yes, the valuation category field exists in the material inventory balance template.

entry.title: SAP Service Cloud release highlights Q4/2025
entry.content:
What is new in SAP Service Cloud? 


Explore a selection of our new features in this blog post and join our webcasts for live demos and deeper insights SAP Service Cloud Version 2 updates. 

Register for our Q4 2025 customer webcast: https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5190303/34D941B16A9727E33187B9FA4DB3DEF7  

Read the SAP CX release highlights blog here

As we begin 2026, let‚Äôs take a look at the capabilities delivered over the past months and how they improve service efficiency and drive customer satisfaction.


AI agent innovations: Faster self-service with intelligent assistance

Let‚Äôs start by taking a look at the new AI agents available for customer service.  As customer service continues to evolve toward closer collaboration between AI and human agents, we are expanding our AI agent portfolio. Our latest AI agent innovations help customers resolve issues faster through self-service while reducing manual effort for service teams.

Digital Service Agent

The Digital Service Agent provides AI-driven, conversational support that helps customers resolve questions quickly through self-service channels using relevant, knowledge-based responses. It reduces customer effort by delivering instant, informed assistance and seamlessly hands over to human agents when needed. By handling routine and high-volume inquiries, the agent helps lower support costs and allows service teams to focus on more complex customer needs.

 


The Utilities Customer Self Service Agent

The Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent supports utilities providers by giving customers easy access to common service features and product offerings through a human-like, conversational experience. By handling high-volume inquiries across multiple channels, it reduces operational costs while maintaining the level of service quality customers expect from human agents. The agent is delivered as an API-only offering, allowing utilities companies to integrate it into a wide range of frontend applications.

 



SAP Service Cloud innovations in Q4: Productivity, visibility, and smarter service workflows

 

Simplify agent workflows with WalkMe in-app guidance

WalkMe, an AI-powered digital adoption platform, is now integrated into SAP Service Cloud to provide intuitive, in-app guidance for service agents. With WalkMe, teams can create step-by-step walkthroughs and contextual tips directly within the application. This simplifies the agent experience, accelerates onboarding, and provides visibility into where agents encounter friction‚Äîhelping organizations continuously optimize their service processes.


Case Management: Create visits directly from a case

Based on customer feedback, we have added the ability to create a follow-up visit directly from a case. This enhancement eliminates manual steps and improves workflow efficiency, helping teams schedule and manage onsite visits more easily and ensure seamless handoffs throughout the service process.


Case Management: Customize KPI cards on Homepage for more efficient case handling

Service teams can now tailor KPI cards on the home page to surface the metrics most relevant to their daily work. With visualizations such as bar charts, donut charts, and other formats, agents gain clearer visibility into priorities and workload distribution, helping them quickly identify where attention is needed.


Customer timeline: Add external business events directly in the timeline

You can now add and display business events from external systems directly in the customer timeline. These events appear alongside emails, interactions, and notes in the standard application, giving service teams a more complete view of relevant activities without switching between applications.

Recent items: Quickly access frequently used objects

Based on customer feedback, we have introduced the Recent items feature to help service agents save time in their daily work. Agents can now access their most recently used objects directly from the application menu, from any page within SAP Service Cloud. This makes it easy to return to ongoing tasks or recently viewed records‚Äîeven after a page refresh‚Äîreducing navigation effort and improving efficiency during day-to-day service activities.

 
Utilities: Gain rapid insights with Generative AI summaries for consumption data

We introduced a new gen AI scenario for Utilities Insights that enables service agents to quickly understand key consumption trends for a premise. With AI-generated summaries of consumption graphs, agents can immediately identify usage fluctuations, anomalies, and important patterns‚Äîsupporting more informed conversations and faster resolution for utilities customers.
New Generative AI Scenario: Utilities Insights | SAP Help Portal

In addition to AI insights, several new features now give utilities agents improved visibility into operational and account-related conditions. Agents can easily see when a premise is disconnected and, where applicable, initiate a reconnection of AMI meters directly from SAP Service Cloud, leveraging seamless integration with SAP S/4HANA.

We have also added clear visibility into contract account locks and contract locks and blocks, helping agents understand any restrictions on billing or service processes right from the contract account view. These enhancements help agents stay better informed and support faster, more confident decision-making during customer interactions.


More information

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 What‚Äôs New  
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 Release Navigator 
  • https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5190303/34D941B16A9727E33187B9FA4DB3DEF7  

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Automating Attachment Purges in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
entry.content:
1. Introduction

As SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central serves as the system of record for workforce data, the volume of employee-related information grows rapidly - particularly attachments stored in core portlets such as Personal Data and Job Information - and not all of it remains relevant over time. Attachments such as outdated documents or redundant files often accumulate silently. While each file may seem insignificant on its own, collectively they can increase storage costs, complicate data management, and introduce unnecessary compliance and security risks.

From a standard SAP SuccessFactors perspective, Data Retention Management (DRTM) already provides mechanisms to purge attachments for MDF-based objects. However, as of now, there is no standard DRTM option available to automatically purge attachments stored in core Employee Central portlets such as Personal Data and Job Information, which is the focus of this blog. The current situation leaves organizations with limited choices beyond manual cleanup or custom development.

This is where automating the purge of attachments in Employee Central becomes essential. An automated approach ensures that obsolete or non-compliant documents are removed consistently and on time, without relying on manual intervention. Beyond improving data hygiene, attachment purge automation helps organizations align with data retention policies, privacy regulations, and audit requirements. In an era where data governance and efficiency are top priorities, proactively managing attachments is no longer optional, it is a critical part of maintaining a healthy and compliant HR system.

In the next section, we‚Äôll explore a straightforward, no-code solution that leverages standard SAP SuccessFactors tools to automate attachment cleanup efficiently and compliantly.

2. Proposed Solution

The proposed solution is based on Integration Center, a standard SAP SuccessFactors tool that allows you to extract, transform, and manage data without the need for custom development. By leveraging Integration Center capabilities, the solution focuses on identifying and purging attachments associated with the Personal Data and Job Information portlets, applying clear business rules to determine which files should be purged.

This approach takes advantage of existing SuccessFactors functionalities to automate the attachment cleanup process in a controlled and auditable way. Without requiring custom code or external middleware, the solution ensures consistency with data retention policies, minimizes manual effort, and reduces the risk of human error. Most importantly, it aligns with security and compliance requirements by ensuring that obsolete or unnecessary documents are removed systematically while preserving critical employee records.

In addition, this solution ensures that attachments are fully purged across the system, removed not only from the originating portlets, but also from Manage Documents and from any associated workflows, should the attachment have been referenced there.

2.1 Solution Steps

Step 1

Go to Integration Center transaction and click ‚ÄúMy Integrations‚Äù.

Step 2

Select ‚Äú+ Create‚Äù and ‚ÄúMore Integration Types‚Äù.

Step 3

Define you integration Type as per below, where we have source and destination as SuccessFactors. Click Create.

Step 4

Search for the portlet name that you want to purge the attachments. In this demo case we used Job Information, but in the same way you can create for Personal Information or Work Permit for example.

Click Select.

Step 5

Give your integration center job a meaningful name and description and click Next.

Step 6

Under the ‚ÄúConfigure Fields‚Äù tab, switch to the ‚ÄúMapping View‚Äù and perform the mapping of the fields as per below.

Step 7

Switch back to the ‚ÄúDetail View‚Äù, click in the attachment field in the left panel and after that click in the ‚ÄúSet as calculated field‚Äù option in the middle of the screen.

Step 8

Define the calculation as per below, where the field value will be equal to ‚Äúnull‚Äù.

Step 9

Now it's time to apply the necessary filters. In our example, we used the filter ‚Äúattachment ‚â† null‚Äù. If other filters are needed for your case, add them as required; for example, only apply the purge to time slices effective up to today's date, meaning future ones should not be considered.

Step 10

Finally, it is time to schedule your new integration job. This will depend on how frequently you want the job to run and clean the attachments.

2.2 How to Test and What is the Expected Outcome

You can quickly test the solution by initiating a data change or any other event, attach a document and save. Once the workflow is approved and the data is saved, verify where the attachments appear in the system. The results should match the example shown below.

Job Information Portlet

Manage Documents

Workflow Details

After completing the initial check, navigate to your integration job, filter the data using the test employee you created, and under the ‚ÄúTest View‚Äù tab, run the job by clicking ‚ÄúRun Preview Records‚Äù.

Once the execution is complete, you will see the result status displayed in the first column.

You can now verify that the attachments have been deleted from all system areas, including the portlet, Manage Documents, and any associated workflows.

Job Information Portlet

Manage Documents

Workflow Details

On the workflow details page, you will notice that the attachment field displays with a standard message which indicates that the document has been purged. If you want to replace this with a more meaningful or user-friendly message, you can customize (Manage Languages Token: ATTACHMENT_ERROR_NO_FETCH) the section highlighted in yellow in the screenshot above.

3. Conclusion

Managing employee attachments effectively is a critical yet often overlooked aspect of maintaining a clean, secure, and compliant SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central environment. As shown throughout this blog, attachments stored in key portlets such as Personal Data and Job Information can quickly accumulate and introduce risks if not governed properly.

By leveraging Integration Center, organizations can implement a simple, no-code, and fully standard solution to automate the purging of obsolete attachments. This approach not only reduces manual effort and operational overhead but also ensures that attachments are consistently and completely removed across Employee Central. The result is improved data hygiene, stronger compliance with retention and privacy policies, and a more sustainable long-term data management strategy.

Ultimately, automating attachment purges is not just a technical optimization, it is a proactive step toward better data governance. With the right configuration and scheduling in place, organizations can ensure their Employee Central system remains efficient, compliant, and ready to support evolving business and regulatory requirements.

I hope this solution helps you improve your Employee Central setup. Feel free to reach out or comment if you have questions, or if you‚Äôd like to share how you‚Äôve tackled attachments purge in your own environment.

entry.title: Billing Plan Template in Service Order Process
entry.content:
You can use an ad hoc billing plan on service order item to define the dates on which billing is to occur and the value that is to be billed. With this you can bill on specific dates and not just when the service order item is completed. For each billing date, you can enter a billing request line (BRL) manually. 

In this blog I am going to explain how you can use a billing plan template so that the system creates such billing request lines and manual creation is no longer necessary.

First, configurations in Customizing must be completed as prerequisites for the automatic creation of billing request lines in an ad hoc billing plan for a service order item. 

 

Create Billing Plan Template

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Create Billing Plan Templates.

After you click on Create button, a new entry screen is displayed. You enter a template ID, a description and a long description. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 1.) 

Figure 1: Define details of a new billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Billing Plan Template Lines on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain line numbers, descriptions, billing value percentage and a date rule. You can also maintain a billing block reason. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 2.) 

 Figure 2: Define billing plan template lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Sales Areas of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain a sales organization, a distribution channel and a division for that the billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 

 Figure 3: Maintain sales are of a billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

You click on node Item Categories of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You choose an item category for that your billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Choose item categories (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Activate Billing Plan Template Determination

You check which billing plan type is assigned to your service order item categories in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Assign Billing Plan Type to Item Category. (See screenshot in Figure 5.)

Figure 5: Billing plan type assignment (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Define Billing Plan Types

You select the billing plan type that you have assigned to service order item categories and open the details.

You flag the checkbox of Determine Billing Plan Template. (See screenshot in Figure 6.) and save it.

Figure 6: Activate determination of billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Quotation

You create a service quotation for customer 17100001 in sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division. You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category SrvItm (Enabl Ad Hoc) (SBQS). (See screenshot in Figure 7.)

Figure 7: Service Quotation Item List (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of item 10 and add the assignment block Billing to the overview page. You maintain the previously created billing plan template in the corresponding field. (See screenshot in Figure 8.)

Figure 8: Assignment block Billing (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Or you open the value help, search with the sales area and select the line for determined billing plan template. (See screenshot in Figure 9.)

Figure 9: Value Help for Billing Plan Template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on Apply and save the service quotation. You send this quotation to the customer (service quotation is released). You click on button Accept. With this, a service order is created as follow-up and the service quotation is completed. You use the link on service order in the assignment block Transaction History. The service order is opened and you check that an item is created.

You open the details of this service order item and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the settings of the billing plan template that you have maintained already in the service quotation item:

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules of the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages of the billing plan template lines.
  • Descriptions are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing blocks are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines, in this example no billing block.

(See screenshot in Figure 10.)

Figure 10: Automatically created billing request lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

What did the system?

  • The billing plan template is copied directly from the service quotation item to the service order item
  • The copied billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Order

You create a service order without predecessor service quotation. So, you enter customer 17100001 for sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division.

You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category Service (Ad Hoc Bil) (SBOS).

You check that the check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value doesn't result in an error message. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.) 

(See screenshot in Figure 11.)

Figure 11: Service Order Item List  (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of service order item 10 and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the data of the determined billing plan template.

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages.
  • Descriptions are copied
  • As no billing block was used in the billing plan template, no billing block is copied.

(See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Order Item Billing Plan (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

What did the system?

  • The determined billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds, and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Notes

If you create a service order item and the system would determine more than one billing plan template, no billing plan template would be applied. The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value would fail and an error message would be displayed (CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604).

 

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the usage of billing plan templates in service order process.

Please don‚Äôt hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

For more details, please visit the full product assistance documentation in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Billing Plan Templates for Ad Hoc Billing Plans in Service Orders | SAP Help Portal
  • Billing Plan Templates in Service Quotations | SAP Help Portal
  • Ad Hoc Billing for Service Orders | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Custom Form with Custom Data Source in SAP Public Cloud (Grow with SAP)
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are scenarios where standard output forms and data sources do not fully meet business requirements.

This blog post explains how to create a custom output form using a custom data source in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Grow with SAP).

The form is developed directly in the S/4HANA Cloud tenant. Please note that this blog post does not cover ‚ÄúSAP Forms service by Adobe‚Äù on SAP Business Technology Platform. Instead, it focuses on form development within the public cloud system itself (Developer Extensibility)

When Should You Follow This Approach?

You should consider creating a custom form with a custom data source in the following scenarios:

  • SAP has not provided a standard data source for the required business object.
    Examples include:

    • Purchase Requisition output

    • Supplier Invoice output (MIRO)

  • You have developed a custom application or custom business object, and an output form is required.
    Since the development is custom, there will naturally be no standard form or data source available for output generation

In such cases, defining a custom data source and binding it to a custom form becomes the correct and often the only viable approach.

When Should You Not Follow This Approach?

You should avoid this approach when a standard solution already exists:

  • If SAP provides a standard data source and a standard form template, you should use them instead of creating custom ones.

    • Example: Purchase Order outputs already have standard data sources and form templates available.

  • When standard data sources are available, always prefer the ‚ÄúForm Template‚Äù Fiori app to customize the output.

Customization of Content Form Templates - SAP S/4HANA Finance

Prerequisites 

Tools

  • Adobe LiveCycle Designer
    Required for designing and modifying Adobe-based output forms. The tool is used to define the layout, structure, and binding of the form fields to the data source.
  • ABAP Development Toolkit (ADT)
    Required for designing and modifying Adobe-based output forms. The tool is used to define the layout, structure, and binding of the form fields to the data source.

Skills

  • Knowledge on Adobe Form
  • Knowledge on RAP Development Framework

Code References

All example code referenced in this article is available in the Git repository linked below. To keep the blog post concise and focused, the source code is not reproduced here in full, as including it would unnecessarily lengthen the post.

GitHub - gourabdey-sap/form-development-in-s4hc: Custom Form Development with Custom Data Source in S4HC

TECHNICAL IMPLEMENTATION

As an example for custom form development using a custom data source, we will use the Purchase Requisition (PR) form. This example is chosen because the Purchase Requisition process is well known and familiar to most readers, making it easier to understand and relate to the concepts discussed.

Step 1 - Custom CDS View Creation

We will create a RAP BO for Purchase Requisition form output requirement. I usually prefer defining a Root CDS view to keep the design future-proof. This approach allows for easy functional enhancements later without requiring changes to the existing CDS hierarchy.

That said, if your objective is only to call the form, a standard CDS view is sufficient. In such cases, creating a Root CDS view (RAP Business Object) is not mandatory.

We will create two interface CDS views and two corresponding consumption CDS views:

  • One set for header data

  • One set for item data

The source code for the CDS can be found in GitHub Repo .

Step 2 - Marking the Header Consumption CDS as Form Data Provider

Add the following annotation to the header consumption CDS view. This annotation is required only for the header consumption view and must not be added to the item CDS view

@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER  ]

Step 3 - Creating Form Data Provider (Data Source)

Next, we need to create a Service Definition to act as the form data provider (data source). Both the header and item entities must be exposed in this service definition. 

An important point to note is the leading entity annotation, defined using @ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name

@EndUserText.label: 'PR Form Data Provider'
@ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name: 'ZMM_C_PRHEADER'
define service ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA {
  expose ZMM_C_PrHeader as Header;
  expose ZMM_C_PrItem   as Item;
}

Key Point Consideration:

  • Only one CDS entity must be designated as the Form Data Provider. In this scenario, the header CDS view (ZMM_C_PrHeader) is the sole data provider and is annotated with @ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER].
    The item CDS view must not contain this annotation.
  • The Service Definition should have the leading entity defined in upper case. The Data Definition name of the header view is ZMM_C_PrHeader still, the leading entity has to be provided as ZMM_C_PRHEADER.
@ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name: 'ZMM_C_PRHEADER'‚Äã
  • Service Binding creation is not required for rendering the form. Only Service Binding is enough,
    But, still in this blog post Service Binding will be required for generation of RAP Application. 

Step 4 - Form Creation

Create new Form using Path: Right Click on Package > New > Other ABAP Repository Object > Form. Provide the form name as required. I have given as ZMM_PR_OUTPUT.

Data Provider: 

Select the data provider as the Service Definition been created in Step 3. In this example, this will be ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA. 

Save the form (Ctrl/Cmd + S). 

Please note: The form cannot be activated yet as the layout is still not developed. 

Step 5 - Download XML Schema (XSD File)

To download the XSD file of form, click on "Download Schema" button.

Click on export and give the file name. I have given the file name as "PR Schema.xsd".

Step 6 - Create Form Layout

Open Adobe LiveCycle Designer (ALD) locally in the system. You can search for the application "Adobe LiveCycle Designer" in your system and should be able to open it, provided this is installed locally in your system.

Once the Adobe LiveCycle Designer is open, click on New Form. Or alternatively you can use the menu File > New Form (Ctrl/Cmd + N) 

Select the orientation as required and click on Finish.

Use the menu File > New Data Connection to link to the XSD file.

Select the XSD file downloaded from Step 5. Click on finish.

The field details can be seen the Data View tab. If you don't have data view tab, then you can add it from the menu Windows > Data View

Rename the Page and bind it to the header Node.

Then save the form as XDP file (Ctrl/Cmd + S).

Step 7 - Designing the Form

As both form is created and the connection is established with XSD file, we can work on the layout development as required.

As an example, I will have a very basic layout where some of the fields from header will be bound and we will have a table which will have item details. 

You would need the data in XML format. We will download it subsequent section. We will also see how to preview the form locally in the system. 

Step 8 - Generate Sample Data

Right click on Preview PDF tab > Select Preview Tab

Click on Generate Preview Data > Click on the button below Data File Name

Provide the name of the file and Click Save. 

Then click on Generate Button, which will generate some sample data. Click on Ok.

With this we have some example data been generated and we can Preview the form locally.

Step 9 - Preview the Form

Click on the Preview Tab to have a look at the form layout been developed.

This is how the form layout appears locally during preview. Some fields are displayed in light blue in the local preview; however, when the form is executed within S/4HANA Cloud (S/4HC), this blue coloring will not be visible.

The sample forms, example data and XSD scheme can be found in GitHub Repo 

Step 10 - Upload the Form in S4

Open the form been created in Step 4 and upload the developed form using Upload Layout. 

Now you should be able to activate the form.

So, we have successfully created the form and uploaded in S4HC.

Step 11 - Adding Attachment Related field in Header Consumption View

For showing the attachment using CDS, we would need below 3 fields

  • File Name - Name of the file
  • Mime Type - For PDF, this will be always
  • Attachment - The PR Output PDF

So, we will achieve this by using virtual element of CDS. 

Important Annotation:

Virtual Field

@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'

Attachment Field

@Semantics.largeObject:{
  mimeType: 'MimeType',
  fileName: 'FileName',
  contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
}

Mime Type

@Semantics.mimeType: true

CDS Source Code

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Requisition Header'
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER ]
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZMM_C_PrHeader
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZMM_I_PrHeader
{
  key     PurchaseRequisition,
          PurReqnDescription,
          PurchaseRequisitionType,
          LastChangeDateTime,
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
  virtual FileName   : abap.char( 50 ),
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
          @Semantics.mimeType: true
  virtual MimeType   : abap.char( 50 ),
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
          @Semantics.largeObject:{
            mimeType: 'MimeType',
            fileName: 'FileName',
            contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
          }
  virtual Attachment : abap.rawstring( 0 ),
          /* Associations */
          _Item : redirected to composition child ZMM_C_PrItem
}

Step 12 - Logic for Virtual Elements 

The calculation class for virtual element should implement the interface if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read.

The interface has 2 methods.

  • get_calculation_info :
    • The fields which are used in the logic required to be added to the field et_requested_orig_elements.
    • For our case, only Purchase Requisition number is enough.
  • calculate:
    • The actual logic for virtual fields will go here. 
    • The required fields have to be populated in internal table ct_calculated_data.

Complete code for the class is available here.

Step 13 - Calling the Adobe Form

Rending the Form (line no 23-31)

  • The form is rendered using the method cl_fp_ads_util=>render_pdf.
  • This requires the data and the layout.

Reading data in XML format (line 9-14)

  • The XML data are being read using the object of CL_FP_FDP_SERVICES. 
  • It requires the key of the Root/Header CDS, which is defined as lead entity in the Service Definition in Step 3. In our case, only Purchase Requisition is the key. If multiple keys are there, value should be passed for all keys.
  • The Purchase requisition data is fetched in the line 13 in the variable LV_DATA in XSTRING format.

Reading data in Form Layout (line no 19)

  • We would also need the form layout (Adobe Form which was designed and uploaded in Step 10) to render the form.
  • The form layout is fetched and assigned to LV_XML in XSTRING format.

Getting reference to Form API

  • Passing the Service Definition created in Step 3 to get the reference.
  • This API will be used to get the data from the Form Data Provider in XML format.
  • The parameter iv_max_depth represents navigation level. In this example, we have Header and Item so, 1 level depth should be fine
  METHOD get_pdf.

    mc_duplicate_call = abap_true.

    DATA(lo_fdp_api) = cl_fp_fdp_services=>get_instance(
      iv_max_depth          = 1
      iv_service_definition = `ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA` ).

    DATA(lt_keys)    = lo_fdp_api->get_keys( ).

    lt_keys[ name = 'PURCHASEREQUISITION' ]-value = im_v_pr.

    DATA(lv_data) = lo_fdp_api->read_to_xml_v2(
      it_select = lt_keys
    ).

    DATA(lv_string) = cl_abap_conv_codepage=>create_in( )->convert( lv_data ).

    DATA(lv_xml) = lo_fdp_api->get_xsd_v2( ).

    DATA(lv_string2) = cl_abap_conv_codepage=>create_in( )->convert( lv_xml ).

    DATA(lo_reader) = cl_fp_form_reader=>create_form_reader( `ZMM_PR_OUTPUT` ).

    DATA(ls_layout) = lo_reader->get_layout( ).

    cl_fp_ads_util=>render_pdf( EXPORTING iv_xml_data   = lv_data
                                          iv_xdp_layout = ls_layout
                                          iv_locale     = 'en_US'
                                IMPORTING ev_pdf        = rt_v_pdf
                                         ).

    mc_duplicate_call = abap_false.

  ENDMETHOD.

Step 14 - Service Binding

Create a Service Binding for the RAP application. This should be OData v4, as attachment does not work in OData V2 using CDS Annotation.

Preview the Application.:

Step 15 - Download the Form

Click the link in the Attachment column of any row to download the PDF. Mission accomplished! üöÄ

CONCLUSION

Below is the recap of the activities done so far

  • Created the necessary CDS views to fetch the required data, covering both header and item information.
  • Designated the header consumption CDS view as the Form Data Provider using the appropriate annotation.
  • Created the Adobe Form in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and exported the corresponding XSD schema.
  • Designed the form layout locally using Adobe LiveCycle Designer, with the XSD schema used for data binding.
  • Generated sample XML data locally and used it to preview and validate the form layout.
  • Uploaded the completed form layout back into S/4HANA Cloud and successfully activated the form.
  • Created the virtual elements in the consumption view for attachments. Logic has been added fill the Filename, Mime Type and PDF.
  • Service Binding has been created for the for the RAP application (OData V4) and able to download the PDF which is a custom form with custom data source.

One More Thing‚Ä¶ üß† (For the Curious Minds)

If you‚Äôve made it this far, here‚Äôs a small challenge for fellow SAP explorers: SAP standard output transactions allow you to download the form XML using the magical command #&&DOWNLOAD_FORM_DATA_XML&&#

Now the fun part:

üëâWhy not bring the same superpower to your custom form?

Try adding a provision to download the XML data using the very same command‚Äînot a workaround, not a shortcut, but exactly the SAP way.
Bonus points if your implementation is so seamless that it feels like it shipped straight from Walldorf üòâ

Signing Off

Shared from experience. Use it, challenge it, and improve it‚Äîlet‚Äôs grow together with SAP Grow.

entry.title: Re: How to Take SAP‚Äôs New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Thanks @Amin_Omidy for your blog, it certainly clarifies the process, and I would certainly recommend to use the yoodil.ai just to get familiar with the platform if this is your first time for the new assessment. I have a few questions which am sure others will be asking as well:

  1. Case Study Availability: Just to clarify, was the case study provided, but I have heard of other having difficulty to locate within the platform?
  2. Download Status: Were you eventually able to find the file, and if so, were you able to download it or you can only read it online?
  3. Material Access: Are the exam materials made available for review before pressing the 'Start' button, or only after the exam has begun?
  4. Time Limit Clarification: Could you please clarify the reference to '24 hours'? My understanding is that there is a 2-hour limit to complete the exam (BTP Solution Architect) once started, so I am unclear what the 24-hour window refers to.
  5. Exam Retake: Is it correct that if we fail the first attempt, we are permitted to retake the exam immediately, provided we have sufficient time remaining? Specifically, the 2-hour window covers both the initial attempt and any necessary retakes? In this case how can we restart the exam to emsure its counted within the same attempt?
  6. Recording Procedures: If we are unable to find the required materials during the exam, are we permitted to stop the recording to search for them, or will stopping the recording end the session?

Many Thanks

entry.title: How can I reserve tools for orders via api?
entry.content:
Simple: I want to use the Reserve tools functionality in the production Order integration. we have NO SAP S/4 Hana.

How I see this there are 2 options:

  1. Via the SAP Digital Manufacturing REST API, but I cannot find any option to add a tool reservation for an order in any API endpoint.
  2. Via a PPD and an custom api endpoint (/pe/api/v1/process/processDefinitions/start?key=). In this case I cannot find any service to add a tool reservation for an order

How can I achieve this functionality?
